name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: [SOUND]

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: This lecture is about natural language

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: content analysis.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Natural language content analysis is the foundation of text mining.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: So we're going to first talk about this.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _And in particular

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: natural language processing with a factor how we can present text data.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: And this determines what algorithms can be used to analyze and mine text data.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: We're going to take a look at the basic concepts in natural language first.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: And I'm going to explain these concepts

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: using a similar example that you've all seen here.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: A dog is chasing a boy on the playground.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Now this is a very simple sentence.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: When we read such a sentence we don't have to think

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: about it to get the meaning of it.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _But when a computer has to understand the sentence

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: the computer has to go through several steps.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _First
column6: the computer needs to know what are the words

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: how to segment the words in English.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _And this is very easy
column6: we can just look at the space. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _And then the computer will need the know the categories of these words

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: syntactical categories.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _So for example
column6: dog is a noun

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: And this is called a Lexical analysis.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _In particular
column6: tagging these words with these syntactic categories _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: is called a part-of-speech tagging.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: After that the computer also needs to figure out the relationship between

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: these words.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: So a and dog would form a noun phrase.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _On the playground would be a prepositional phrase
column6: etc. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: And there is certain way for them to be connected together in order for

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: them to create meaning.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Some other combinations may not make sense.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _And this is called syntactical parsing
column6: or _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _syntactical analysis
column6: parsing of a natural language sentence. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: The outcome is a parse tree that you are seeing here.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _That tells us the structure of the sentence
column6: so _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: that we know how we can interpret this sentence.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: But this is not semantics yet.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: So in order to get the meaning we would have to map these phrases and

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: these structures into some real world antithesis that we have in our mind.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _So dog is a concept that we know
column6: and boy is a concept that we know. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: So connecting these phrases that we know is understanding.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Now for a computer
column6: would have to formally represent these entities by using symbols. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _So dog
column6: d1 means d1 is a dog. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Boy
column6: b1 means b1 refers to a boy etc. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: And also represents the chasing action as a predicate.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _So
column6: chasing is a predicate here with _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _three arguments
column6: d1

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Which is playground.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: So this formal rendition of the semantics of this sentence.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Once we reach that level of understanding
column6: we might also make inferences. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _For example
column6: if we assume there's a rule that says if someone's being chased then _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _the person can get scared
column6: then we can infer this boy might be scared. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _This is the inferred meaning
column6: based on additional knowledge. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _And finally
column6: we might even further infer _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _what this sentence is requesting

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _or why the person who say it in a sentence
column6: is saying the sentence. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _And so
column6: this has to do with purpose of saying the sentence. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: This is called speech act analysis or pragmatic analysis.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Which first to the use of language.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _So
column6: in this case a person saying this may be reminding another person to _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: bring back the dog.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _So this means when saying a sentence
column6: the person actually takes an action. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: So the action here is to make a request.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Now
column6: this slide clearly shows that in order to really understand _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: a sentence there are a lot of things that a computer has to do.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Now
column6: in general it's very hard for a computer will do everything

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: especially if you would want it to do everything correctly.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: This is very difficult.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Now
column6: the main reason why natural language processing is very difficult

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: it's because it's designed it will make human communications efficient.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _As a result
column6: for example
column7: with only a lot of common sense knowledge. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Because we assume all of us have this knowledge

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: there's no need to encode this knowledge.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: That makes communication efficient.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _We also keep a lot of ambiguities
column6: like

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _And this is again
column6: because we assume we have the ability to disambiguate the word. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _So
column6: there's no problem with having the same word to mean _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: possibly different things in different context.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Yet for a computer this would be very difficult

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: because a computer does not have the common sense knowledge that we do.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: So the computer will be confused indeed.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: And this makes it hard for natural language processing.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Indeed
column6: it makes it very hard for _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: every step in the slide that I showed you earlier.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Ambiguity is a main killer.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Meaning that in every step there are multiple choices

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: and the computer would have to decide whats the right choice and

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: that decision can be very difficult as you will see also in a moment.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _And in general

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: we need common sense reasoning in order to fully understand the natural language.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: And computers today don't yet have that.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: That's why it's very hard for

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: computers to precisely understand the natural language at this point.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: So here are some specific examples of challenges.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Think about the world-level ambiguity.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _A word like design can be a noun or a verb
column6: so _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: we've got ambiguous part of speech tag.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Root also has multiple meanings
column6: it can be of mathematical sense

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _like in the square of
column6: or can be root of a plant. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Syntactic ambiguity refers to different interpretations

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: of a sentence in terms structures.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _So for example

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: natural language processing can actually be interpreted in two ways.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: So one is the ordinary meaning that we

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: will be getting as we're talking about this topic.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _So
column6: it's processing of natural language. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: But there's is also another possible interpretation

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: which is to say language processing is natural.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Now we don't generally have this problem
column6: but imagine for the computer to determine _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _the structure
column6: the computer would have to make a choice between the two. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Another classic example is a man saw a boy with a telescope.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: And this ambiguity lies in the question who had the telescope?

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: This is called a prepositional phrase attachment ambiguity.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Meaning where to attach this prepositional phrase with the telescope.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Should it modify the boy?

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Or should it be modifying
column6: saw

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Another problem is anaphora resolution.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: In John persuaded Bill to buy a TV for himself.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Does himself refer to John or Bill?

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Presupposition is another difficulty.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _He has quit smoking implies that he smoked before
column6: and _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: we need to have such a knowledge in order to understand the languages.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Because of these problems
column6: the state of the art natural language processing _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: techniques can not do anything perfectly.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Even for the simplest part of speech tagging

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: we still can not solve the whole problem.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _The accuracy that are listed here
column6: which is about 97%

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: was just taken from some studies earlier.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: And these studies obviously have to be using particular data sets so

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: the numbers here are not really meaningful if you

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: take it out of the context of the data set that are used for evaluation.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _But I show these numbers mainly to give you some sense about the accuracy

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: or how well we can do things like this.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: It doesn't mean any data set accuracy would be precisely 97%.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _But
column6: in general
column7: we can do parsing speech tagging fairly well although not perfect. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Parsing would be more difficult
column6: but for partial parsing

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _phrases correct
column6: we can probably achieve 90% or better accuracy. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _But to get the complete parse tree correctly is still very
column6: very difficult. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _For semantic analysis
column6: we can also do some aspects of semantic analysis

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _particularly
column6: extraction of entities and relations. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _For example
column6: recognizing this is the person

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: this person and that person met in some place etc.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: We can also do word sense to some extent.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: The occurrence of root in this sentence refers to the mathematical sense etc.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Sentiment analysis is another aspect of semantic analysis that we can do.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: That means we can tag the senses as generally positive when

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: it's talking about the product or talking about the person.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Inference
column6: however
column8: and we generally cannot do that for _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: any big domain and if it's only feasible for a very limited domain.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: And that's a generally difficult problem in artificial intelligence.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Speech act analysis is also very difficult and

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: we can only do this probably for very specialized cases.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: And with a lot of help from humans to annotate enough data for

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: the computers to learn from.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: So the slide also shows that

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: computers are far from being able to understand natural language precisely.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: And that also explains why the text mining problem is difficult.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Because we cannot rely on mechanical approaches or

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: computational methods to understand the language precisely.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _Therefore
column6: we have to use whatever we have today. _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: A particular statistical machine learning method of statistical analysis methods

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: to try to get as much meaning out from the text as possible.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: _And
column6: later you will see that there are actually _

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: many such algorithms that can indeed extract

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: interesting model from text even though we cannot really fully understand it.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: Meaning of all the natural language sentences precisely.

name: 2 - 3 - 1.3 Natural Language Content Analysis- Part 1 (00-12-48).srt
text: [MUSIC]
